questions.text: A Child presented with decreased lower limb pulses, which were also delayed, as compared to the upper limb pulses. Likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Decreased lower limb pulses, which were also delayed as compared to the upper limb pulses(radiofemoral delay) suggestive of Coarctation of Aorta.

Incorrect Options:

  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD):
    • VSD is a congenital heart defect where there is an abnormal opening in the septum between the ventricles. This condition does not typically present with pulse delaybetween upper and lower limbs. It is more often associated with a murmur and signs of heart failure, but not with pulse discrepancies.
  • Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA):
    • TGA is a congenital heart defect where the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are reversed. While it can lead to significant cyanosis and heart failure, it doesn't typically present with the pulse delayobserved in coarctation of the aorta.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF):
    • TOF is a congenital heart defect that involves four heart malformations, leading to cyanosisand heart murmurs. While it can cause oxygenation issues, it does not typically result in pulse delay or the pattern of discrepancies between the upper and lower limb pulses seen in coarctation of the aorta.

Atrial Septal Defect: Causes a murmur, not hypertension or differential pulses.

Bicuspid Aortic Valve: Linked to aortic stenosis or regurgitation, not the specific findings here.

Patent Ductus Arteriosus: Typically causes a continuous murmur, not pulse differences or rib notching.

Key takeaways: Coarctation of Aorta


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Hemophilia A, Except?
questions.solution:
• Any clotting factor defect will present with deep tissue bleeding like joint bleeds, muscle bleeds etc.
  • Any platelet defect will present with superficial bleeds like petechiae and mucosal bleeds.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by defective synthesis of clotting factor VIII. It is a clotting factor defect, which typically presents with deep tissue bleeding like hemarthrosis (bleeding into the joints).

As it is X linked recessive, it will affect mostly males.

Incorrect Options:

  • X-linked recessive inheritance:
    • Hemophilia A is indeed inherited in an X-linked recessive This means the defective gene is located on the X chromosome, and it primarily affects males. Females are generally carriers but can be affected if both X chromosomes have the defect, though this is rare.
  • More common in males:
    • As hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, it is more common in males because they have only one X chromosome. If that X carries the defective gene, they will manifest the disease. Females, with two X chromosomes, would need both X chromosomes to carry the defective gene to be affected, which is much rarer.
  • Due to Factor VIII deficiency:
    • Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency of Factor VIII, which is essential for blood clotting. This leads to poor clot formation and difficulty stopping bleeding after injury, especially in deep tissues like joints and muscles.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Handedness is established in a child at what age?
questions.solution:
Handedness: dominance of one hand over the other for performing tasks or activities.

It is established in children at around 3 years.

key takeaways:

Bidextrous grasp -4 months

Unidextrous grasp-6 months

Palmar grasp-7 months

Pincer grasp (immature)-9month

Pincer grasp (mature)-12month

Handedness-3 years

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text:
Assertion: Mousy odour occurs in Phenylketonuria
Reason: There is decrease in tyrosine, dopamine and noradrenaline in these patients causing this odour
questions.solution:
In phenylketonuria (PKU), there is an elevated level of phenylalanine, which is converted into phenylpyruvate. Phenylpyruvate is further metabolized into phenyllactate, which is excreted in the urine. The excretion of phenyllactate imparts a characteristic "mousy/musty odor" to the urine.

Key takeaways: Phenylketonuria

  • Inheritance -+ AR
  • Cause - 90-95% cases Deficiency in phenylalanine hydraxylase: 3-5% cases Defect of cofactor of phenylalanine hydroxylase called Tetrahydrobiopterin.

clinical Features:

Normal at birth - CNS toxicity in 1° year of life

Seizures

Mental Retardation

  • Microcephaly

Hypopigmentation - Fair skin, blonde hair, blue eyes blue eyed blondes with mental retardation

Diagnosis:

  • old - Guthrie's test
  • New & preferred -> Neonatal Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) on dried blood sample
  • Ferric chloride test :Green colour present

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Most childhood UTI caused by Streptococcus pneumonia
All recurrent UTI need US Abdomen on follow-up
MCU may be needed in recurrent UTI
Bladder and bowel dysfunction increases the risk of UTI in children

questions.text: Regarding childhood UTI, all of the following are true except?
questions.solution:
Most childhood UTIs are caused by E.coli>Klebsiella>pseudomonas>proteus.

All recurrent UTIs need US Abdomen on follow-up to rule out congenital malformations.

MCU may be needed in recurrent UTI to diagnose VUR

Incorrect Options:

  • All recurrent UTI need US Abdomen on follow-up:
    • Ultrasound (US) of the abdomen is indeed recommended for children who experience recurrent UTIs. The ultrasound is used to rule out congenital anomalies of the urinary tract (such as hydronephrosis, renal scarring, or obstructions) that could predispose to recurrent infections.
  • MCU may be needed in recurrent UTI:
    • MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram)is a radiologic test used to evaluate for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which is a condition where urine flows backward from the bladder into the kidneys. VUR is a common cause of recurrent UTIs, and if suspected, an MCU may be required to assess for this condition.
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction increases the risk of UTI in children:
    • Bladder and bowel dysfunction, such as constipation or urinary retention, can indeed increase the risk of UTIs in children. These conditions can interfere with proper emptying of the bladder, leading to stasis of urine and an increased risk of infection.

Key Takeaway:

UTI in Children

Sex Differences:

Infants (<1 year): Males > Females (hematogenous spread).

Older Children: Females > Males (ascending infections).

Common Bacteria:

E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Pseudomonas.

Types:

Upper UTI (Pyelonephritis): Fever, chills, systemic signs, renal scarring.

Lower UTI (Cystitis/Urethritis): Dysuria, frequency, burning micturition.

Symptoms:

Infants: Fever, poor feeding, irritability, failure to thrive.

Older Children: Fever, dysuria, pain, hematuria (gross or microscopic).

Investigations:

Urine Microscopy: Centrifuged >5 WBC/HPF; Uncentrifuged >10 WBC/mm³.

Dipstick Test: Detects nitrites, leucocyte esterase.

Urine Culture: Gold standard for diagnosis.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text:
In a child with recurrent UTIs, what is the order of performing investigation in importance on follow-up?
a. Ultrasound
b. Micturating Cystourethrogram
c. DMSA Scan
questions.solution:
Order of performing investigation in importance on follow-up:

I)USG: Immediately after UTI diagnosis ,To assess anatomy and obstruction

ii)MCU: 2-3 weeks post-treatment ,To check for VUR.

iii)DMSA: 2-3 months post-treatment (early DMSA not routine),To detect renal scarring.

Key takeaways: Recurrent UTI


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

choices.text: Most Common cause of Non-Syndromic NHL in children
Confirmation can be done by urine culture or PCR after 4 weeks of age
In developing countries, primary maternal infection can lead to congenital CMV

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Congenital CMV Infection?
questions.solution:
In Congenital CMV Infection cases 90% cases are Asymptomatic & 10% are symptomatic.

Incorrect Options:

  • Most Common cause of Non-Syndromic NHL in children:
    • This is incorrect. Non-Syndromic Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) is not associated with congenital CMV NHL in children is more likely to be associated with other factors, such as immunodeficiency or genetic mutations. CMV is not a common cause of NHL.
  • Confirmation can be done by urine culture or PCR after 4 weeks of age:
    • This is incorrect. Confirmation of congenital CMV infection is typically done by urine PCR or culture within the first 3 weeks of life (not after 4 weeks), as the virus is most reliably detected early after birth. Urine PCR is considered the best method for diagnosing congenital CMV infection.
  • In developing countries, primary maternal infection can lead to congenital CMV:
    • This is correct, but the question asks for the most accurate statement. Primary maternal infection can indeed lead to congenital CMV, but the key point in this question was about the asymptomatic nature of the infection, which makes B the correct answer.

Key takeaways:Congenital CMV

Epidemiology: 90% Asymptomatic

10% symptomatic

C/F in symptomatic cases: IUGR,

Petechiae(Thrombocytopenia)

Sometimes blueberry muffin rash

Microcephaly +/- ,Periventricular Calcification

Chorioretinitis

HSM(HepatoSplenomegaly)

Complications:

SNHL: more common in symptomatic,but can occurs in asymptomatic cases

Hearing assessment in all suspected congenital CMV cases should be done

Schedule:At birth,then every 6 monthly till 2 years of age

By OAE(OtoAcoustic Emission )

Investigation:

Best sample - Urine > Saliva

IOC -PCR

Culture(Urine culture)-confirmatory/gold standard

Rx:

DOC iv Ganciclovir x 6week specially recommended in CNS & eye involvement

Alternative Oral Valganciclovir x 6 month

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 8 year old child presents with an acute exacerbation of asthma with life-threatening features. What should be done immediately?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Option Explanation:

A. CXR and decide therapy

  • This is incorrectas a priority during a life-threatening asthma exacerbation. A CXR (chest X-ray) is not needed immediately unless there is concern about other complications (e.g., pneumothorax or pneumonia). The first priority is managing the airway with oxygen, corticosteroids, and bronchodilators, not diagnostic imaging.

Asthma severity & menagement


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Parents complain that their child is always tired, gets fatigued more if climbs stairs and also develops episodes of breathlessness in supine position. What is the investigation to perform for likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Spirometry: While spirometry can be helpful in assessing respiratory conditions(like asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), the symptoms described are more suggestive of a cardiac issue rather than a primary lung condition. Spirometry would not be the first investigation to address a potential heart issue.
  • Chest X-ray: A chest X-ray could provide information about the lungs, heart size, or fluid buildupbut is not as detailed or specific as echocardiography when assessing the heart's structure and function.
  • MRI Thorax: MRI thorax is a more specialized and detailed imaging modality used in certain cardiac conditions, but echocardiography is typically the first-line and most accessible investigation for suspected cardiac issues, especially in children.

Key Takeaway:


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An 11 year old child has Acute Rheumatic Fever and has no cardiac manifestations. What should be the duration of antibiotic prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Secondary prevention/prevention of complications in ARF:

Antibiotic prophylaxis:

Intramuscular benzathine penicillin or

Oral penicillin or

Oral sulfadiazine or

Duration of Antibiotic prophylaxis AHA guidelines


Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: An Alternate way to measure height in a 4 year old child involves which among the following?
questions.solution:
Growth disorders:


Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Head Circumference: Head circumference is a useful measure in infants and toddlers for monitoring growth and brain development, but it does not directly correlate with overall height.
  • Crown-Rump Length: Crown-rump length is used in infants or young children, particularly when the child is lying down, to estimate gestational age and growth. However, it is not a reliable method to measure height for a 4-year-old child.
  • Knee Height: Knee height is another potential measure used in young children(especially when standing height is difficult to measure), but arm span is considered a more accurate and commonly used alternate method for height assessment in children aged 4 years.

Key Takeaways:

  • Arm span is a reliable alternative to direct height measurement in children around 4 years old, especially when other methods are not feasible.
  • Head circumference and crown-rump length are more commonly used for growth monitoring in infants and young children but are not reliable for measuring height in a 4-year-old.
  • Knee height is also a method used in some cases but is less commonly used than arm span for height estimation in children of this age.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric

questions.text: Requirements for IV cannulating a newborn shall include?
questions.solution:
Cannula size & color


IV cannulation a newborn

  • Adequate light

Ensure complete aseptic precautions

Wear gloves

Stabilize child

  • Take appropriate size cannula

In Newborn smallest size cannula 26G is used

22G is bigger used in beyond infancy

  • Create adequate position of child: Flex the palm at wrist joint
  • Ideally apply tourniquet

In newborns tourniquet is not mandatory,because there is small hand.only by pressing hand vein will become prominent

  • Choose appropriate vein
  • Insert the Cannula catheter
  • Apply the tape/fixatOr
  • Flush the Cannula by Normal saline by using small 1-2ml syringe because blood is coming backward in Cannula, there is risk of Clot formation.

Reference: Nelson textbook of paediatric
